body: Currently Druid is only known to run on Unix systems. Closing this issue until we decide to offer support for Windows.

@swistakm the library we use for dependency resolution does not provide much error handling, if any.
We should probably catch those exceptions and try to offer pointers for resolution, but it's not going to be perfect.
Closing this since there currently are no plans to support additional dependencies, only removing them.
Conversations directly with FJ and others who have commented on this PR show that everyone is generally ok with this, so I went ahead and merged.

ok, we probably need better tests for this, but if everyone's comfortable that's fine with me.
Since this in general makes things better, I'm removing myself as a blocker here
@guobingkun can you squash your commits, and I'll merge.

@nishantmonu51 Ok, That seems reasonable.  One last question: What will happen if locks are in the metadata store, but the ZK is completely wiped.  Will the system recover on its own, or will it deadlock?

@nishantmonu51 I'm mostly interested in making sure that the changes you are introducing won't adversely affect what's there.  Like, will the permanency of the znodes cause thigns to become better, worse, or same?

It definitely makes things better in case of zk disconnections when nodes get disconnected due to network issues or load issues with zk. 
In case of complete zk state wipeout, things will be same as of today i believe.

@nishantmonu51, are you wondering what would happen in the current code? Currently the thing that manages the locks (the lockbox) and the thing that interacts with ZK (the RTR) are totally separate. The contract is that the RTR needs to resolve the futures it returned from "run" when it decides that a task is no longer running, and as long as it does that correctly, the lockbox won't contain any stale locks that might cause deadlocks.

I think the current behavior if ZK is wiped while the overlord and middle managers are down is that the overlord will load up the marked-as-running tasks and their locks from the metadata storage, then pass them all to the RTR, which would cause them to start running again (since the RTR won't see any of the markers in ZK that indicated this was done already). Then it should resolve them as usual once they finish.

yeah, i was wondering about the current code, as this PR makes changes to ensure that RTR and MM state remains in sync during ZK disconnects, but it can still get out of sync in case of total ZK cleanup.

@cheddar, to answer your question things wont be permanently broken and system will recover.

Ok, if we believe that this PR won't make things worse, then great.

Fwiw, we recently had to restore our DB from a backup that had stale locks in it.  Those locks never actually got cleaned up until we manually went in and deleted all lock entries from the DB.  This did cause a bit of indexing deadlock for us.  So, the current behavior can be improved as well.  Given that this won't make that any worse and the system will continue to operate correctly if ZK is compeletely wiped out, I have no objections.
@xvrl Done.

:+1:  Will leave this for a day or so to see if anyone else wants to read/comment.  If not, we can just merge.

@cheddar @guobingkun nothing wrong with the test per se, but I feel there's quite a bit of overlap between this and `BatchServerInventoryViewTest`. It seems like we're testing both here. Maybe we can move the ZK related tests to `BatchServerInventoryViewTest`, and simply mock `ServerInventoryView` to focus on testing `BrokerServerView` by itself?
LGTM

Hi @xvrl, I prefer to use a concrete `BatchServerInventoryViewclass` here since it is easy to create and it makes the test more realistic given `BrokerServerView` depends on it heavily. I don't see any harm to conveniently test `BatchServerInventoryView` again in a different place though. Not sure if it is trivial to move ZK related stuff since `BatchServerInventoryViewTest` doesn't inherit `CuratorTestBase`

This seems dangerous as it is essentially adding Java Script as an official language for core functionality. I assume the reason for this is "deploying javascript strategies is faster than deploying modules". This feels like it could introduce some complications, and lack of general capacity for unit testing, and lack of general documentation for how to get useful stuff from the parameters in java script, means that community use could be very frustrating.

If "faster than deploying modules" functionality really is required, then I propose moving this to an extension module, and making it very clear that the functionality is provided, but cannot be supported by the dev team and is intended to be a development aide rather than a production extension.
One failure mode not captured here is if `config.getInfoDir` points to a non-directory file system entry.
I'm good here if @cheddar feels the comments are outside the scope of this PR.

@drcrallen inspired me to clean up this code a bit.  I've now expanded this PR to also include changes that separate out the bootstrapping threads from the loading threads.

Also, the usage of exceptions that are just going to get caught in the exact same method isn't really great, so I undid them and removed the need to store a full list of Futures.
@cheddar That sounds like a good direction.
LGTM, adding a count of failed segments would be more helpful than the list of segments we had before to gauge severity of alert, see my comment above.

In general the java script stuff is good for rapid development of missing features. I'm good here if we can do 2 things:

1) Show a more complex example in the unit test, preferably using each of the 3 args at least once somewhere in the unit tests.
2) Put a little more documentation in the new docs about when the javascript one is the appropriate choice compared to writing a java one.
I will add a more elaborative example that can be used in real world.
:+1: @conradlee Can you sign the CLA at http://druid.io/community/cla.html?

@nishantmonu51 increasing reps only has minimal impact on node lookup time, most of the difference is due to the change in hash function.

verifies the fix #1120

looks like it should fix the case mentioned in #713 ?
we put the hadoop libs and extension jars explicitly on the classpath. please make sure that this change does not break other existing setups like those.

@himanshug the extension class loader uses the root loader as a fallback, so anything on your root CLASSPATH that doesn't exist in extension dependency hierarchy (e.g. your yarn configs) will still be discoverable. It impacts only the case where extension's hadoop dependency has a version (2.3.0) different than your hadoop version. Now that extension's own hadoop is being preferred over your hadoop, a version conflict is possible. However, it is recommended to recompile druid to match your hadoop version anyway.
@nishantmonu51 : We actually do that currently. That issue might be resolved.
I'm going to cancel this for now because I think it is too risky without more thorough investigation.
Do we need to tag this for inclusion in release notes somehow?

Haven't looked deeply yet, but one high level thought that came to mind.  It looks like this is changing the same logic that would pull down the segments from deep storage for historical nodes and stuff.

Seems like it might be nice to separate it out so that there is a separate loader that does the version stuff and leave the old code untouched?
@cheddar It does not change anything currently. It adds a `getLatestVersion(final URI uri, final Pattern pattern)` method which is not actually called in this code, but is called in the QTL PR

@pjain1 this is causing things to break in current master. We Need to add serde tests for when `tieredReplicants` is `null`
@xvrl I am looking into it.
@xvrl I was thinking how can `tieredReplicants` be `null` ? Are you not using coordinator console and setting rules programmatically ?
@pjain1 it's required for backwards compatibility with rules that were setup for when tiers didn't exist.
@xvrl I see. Thanks. PR for the fix - https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1462

Thanks for the fix!

Can you clarify the following by way of unit tests:
1. If a `tieredReplicants` is NULL in json, should the resulting property be null or empty-map?
2. If a `tieredReplicants` is NULL, should reflecting json result in the same original json?

In the prior behavior it did result in the same json. If I'm reading this correctly this PR changes such behavior.

There is precedence for such behavior in numerous other POJOs around Druid, but it would be nice to get the weigh-in of someone more familiar with the Replicant Tiering code to comment on if this change will be an issue.

@drcrallen Yes it changes the behavior. `tieredReplicants` can be set to `null` instead of an empty Map however in that case wouldn't `getNumReplicants(String tier)` method and `getTieredReplicants()` in `run` method of `LoadRule` throw NPE?
